headline: Qualcomm Prevails on Key Issues in Arm Suit
summary: A Delaware jury ruled that Qualcomm had a valid license to use Arm’s basic chip architecture for central processors it developed with the acquisition of a startup called Nuvia in 2021.  The ruling paved the way for Qualcomm to continue selling those chips, which are at the heart of a range of devices including Microsoft Surface laptops.  Qualcomm’s stock rose 1.8% in after-hours trading, while Arm’s stock fell 1.7%.

Qualcomm’s stock rose 1.8% in after-hours trading, while Arm’s stock fell 1.7%.

headline: Qualcomm Defeats Arm’s Claim Over Chip Design License Breach
summary: (Bloomberg) -- Qualcomm Inc. prevailed at trial against Arm Holdings Plc’s claim that it breached a license for chip technology that the world’s largest maker of mobile-phone processors acquired when it bought a startup in 2021. headline: Qualcomm Scores a Victory in Its Dispute With Longtime Partner Arm
summary: This was a unique case in which Arm sued one of its best customers.  The falling-out between the partners arose in 2022 when Arm claimed that Qualcomm violated the terms of a licensing agreement it had with Nuvia, a company that Qualcomm bought in 2021 for $1.4 billion.  Qualcomm countered that the technology that was transferred from Nuvia was covered under its own license agreement with Arm.

headline: Qualcomm scores major legal victory against Arm over chip designs
summary: Investing.com -- Qualcomm scored a major legal victory on Friday when a U.S. jury determined that the company didn't violate its licensing agreement for UK-based Arm 's chip designs following its acquisition of Nuvia.

raw.headline: Qualcomm scores major legal victory against Arm over chip designs

headline: Qualcomm not in breach of Nuvia-Arm licensing deal, jury finds
summary: A jury found that Qualcomm (QCOM) didn't violate Nuvia's licensing agreement with Arm Holdings (ARM) and properly licensed its CPU (central processing unit) design. Qualcomm completed its acquisition of Nuvia in March 2021. Market Domination Overtime hosts Seana Smith and Josh Lipton report on this breaking verdict for these semiconductor manufacturers. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime here. This post was written by Luke Carberry Mogan.

headline: Qualcomm processors are properly licensed from Arm, U.S. jury finds
summary: Arm Holdings' lawsuit against Qualcomm ended on Friday with a jury delivering a mixed verdict that found for Qualcomm on a crucial issue, saying Qualcomm had properly licensed its central processor chips. Arm's shares were down 1.9% in extended trade after the news, and Qualcomm shares were up 2.3%.

headline: US jury deadlocked in Arm trial against Qualcomm, still deliberating
summary: A jury in U.S. federal court in Delaware on Friday said it was deadlocked on one of the questions that it has been asked to resolve in Arm Holdings' lawsuit against Qualcomm, but is still deliberating...
